reasoning:
The critique targets the paper’s benchmarking/framing move: defining “best feasible” via a percentile of a (purportedly) no-de-dicto-optimization distribution and then judging how hard it is to reach 0.5/0.9 of that ceiling. If that were the paper’s operative definition, it would meaningfully weaken some of the paper’s “narrow target”/“far from the ceiling” framing, but it wouldn’t collapse the core drivers of the thesis (value fragility across many dimensions; many plausible moral views being ‘fussy’). Hence moderate centrality.

Strength is moderate because the endogeneity point is a real conceptual issue for any percentile-relative ceiling: feasibility/upper-tail outcomes can change with governance/optimization regimes, so a fixed ceiling can be non–policy-invariant. However, the paper’s later, more formal definition of “best feasible” is not clearly conditional on the no-optimization regime in the way the critique alleges; rather, the “no serious de dicto optimization” conditioning is primarily used to define the baseline likelihood of mostly-great outcomes (fussiness), not necessarily to define the ceiling itself. That misread blunts the refutation.

Correctness is fairly high: the general ‘shifting ceiling/endogeneity’ concern and the suggested fix (policy-class-conditioned feasibility or explicit modeling of feasibility vs optimization) are basically right, but the critique likely overstates that the paper “bakes in” no-optimization into the best-feasible definition.

Clarity is high, dead weight is low, and it stays focused on a single issue.
title: "Circularity in defining the 'best feasible' benchmark"
